form.preferredDefinition: The DI-PAD or Diagnostic Instrument for Psychoses and Affective Disorders is an 83 question interviewer-administered instrument designed to elicit information regarding a research subject's functioning and psychopathology with particular emphasis on affective disorders and schizophrenia. It is an American-English adaptation of the Diagnostic Interview for Psychoses ((DIP) Castle et al., 2006)

question.questionText: 1. Source of rating (OPCRIT 1) (source_of_rating)

validValue.meaningText: Combined sources not including structured interview
validValue.description: Combined sources not including structured interview

question.questionText: 2. Sex code (OPCRIT 3) (sex_code)
3. How old are you? (pxt120701_age)
4. Single (OPCRIT 6) (single)

validValue.meaningText: Are you married, have you ever been married or lived with the same partner for at least six months?
validValue.description: Are you married, have you ever been married or lived with the same partner for at least six months?

validValue.meaningText: Single; has never married or lived as married
validValue.description: Single; has never married or lived as married

question.questionText: I would like to ask you about the first time you became ill with a psychiatric problem. When did you first experience psychiatric problems? When did others first say that they thought you had a psychiatric problem? How old were you when you first received treatment? Can you tell me about that? (age_of_onset)

I would like to ask you about the first time you became ill with a psychiatric problem. When did you first experience psychiatric problems? When did others first say that they thought you had a psychiatric problem? How old were you when you first received treatment? Can you tell me about that? (age_of_onset_coded)

How did that first episode of psychiatric illness start? Did the problem start quickly, or was there a long period when you knew you were becoming ill? How long would you say that was? (mode_of_onset)

validValue.meaningText: Abrupt onset definable within hours or days
validValue.description: Abrupt onset definable within hours or days

validValue.meaningText: Acute onset definable within one month
validValue.description: Acute onset definable within one month

validValue.meaningText: Moderately acute onset definable within one month
validValue.description: Moderately acute onset definable within one month

validValue.meaningText: Gradual onset over period up to six months
validValue.description: Gradual onset over period up to six months

validValue.meaningText: Insidious onset over period greater than six months
validValue.description: Insidious onset over period greater than six months

question.questionText: Notes about age and mode of onset: (notes_about_age_mode_onset)

module.longName: 7. Psychosocial stressors prior to onset of first episode

instruction.text: A severely or moderately severely threatening event has occurred prior to onset of disorder that is unlikely to have resulted from the subject's own behavior (i.e., the event can be seen as independent or uncontrollable). Examples: Natural disaster (e.g., fire, flood, hurricane, tornado, earthquake) Transportation accident (e.g., car or boat accident, train wreck, plane crash) Serious accident at work, home, or during recreational activity (e.g., accident with machinery, explosion, exposure to toxic substances) Physical assault (e.g., being attacked, hit, slapped, kicked, beaten up) Assault with a weapon (e.g., shot or stabbed, threatened with knife, gun, bomb) Sexual assault (e.g., rape, attempted rape, made to perform any type of sexual act through force or threat of harm) Combat or exposure to a war zone (in the military or as a civilian) Captivity (e.g., being kidnapped, abducted, held hostage, prisoner of war) Life threatening illness or injury Sudden, violent death (for example, homicide, suicide) or serious injury, harm or death you caused to someone else

module.preferredDefinition: 7. Psychosocial stressors prior to onset of first episode

question.questionText: A severely or moderately severely threatening event has occurred prior to onset of disorder that is unlikely to have resulted from the subject's own behavior (i.e., the event can be seen as independent or uncontrollable). Examples: Natural disaster (e.g., fire, flood, hurricane, tornado, earthquake) Transportation accident (e.g., car or boat accident, train wreck, plane crash) Serious accident at work, home, or during recreational activity (e.g., accident with machinery, explosion, exposure to toxic substances) Physical assault (e.g., being attacked, hit, slapped, kicked, beaten up) Assault with a weapon (e.g., shot or stabbed, threatened with knife, gun, bomb) Sexual assault (e.g., rape, attempted rape, made to perform any type of sexual act through force or threat of harm) Combat or exposure to a war zone (in the military or as a civilian) Captivity (e.g., being kidnapped, abducted, held hostage, prisoner of war) Life threatening illness or injury Sudden, violent death (for example, homicide, suicide) or serious injury, harm or death you caused to someone else (inst120701)
What was going on in your life when you first became ill? Were there a lot of stresses in your life at that time? Can you tell me what sort of things were going on then? (psychosocial_stressors)
Notes about psychological stressors (psychosocial_stressors_notes)
At the time you first became ill, were you working or studying full time, a homemaker, or retired? (employment_status)

validValue.meaningText: Employed at onset (includes full time students and homemakers)
validValue.description: Employed at onset (includes full time students and homemakers)

instruction.text: (If student ask about studies if homemaker ask about standard of housework.) Refers to work history before onset of illness. If working and unable to keep any job for more than six months, had a history of frequent changes of job or was only able to sustain a job well below that expected by his/her educational level or training at time of first psychiatric contact. If homemaker and persistently very poor standard of housework. If student and badly failing to keep up with studies.

question.questionText: (If student ask about studies if homemaker ask about standard of housework.) Refers to work history before onset of illness. If working and unable to keep any job for more than six months, had a history of frequent changes of job or was only able to sustain a job well below that expected by his/her educational level or training at time of first psychiatric contact. If homemaker and persistently very poor standard of housework. If student and badly failing to keep up with studies. (inst_120701)
Tell me about jobs you had before you became ill? What was the longest time you worked in one job before you first became ill? (premorbid_work_adjustment)

instruction.text: Refers to social adjustment before onset of illness. Rate if subject found difficulty entering or maintaining normal social relationships, showed persistent social isolation, withdrawal or maintained solitary interests prior to onset of psychotic symptoms.

question.questionText: Refers to social adjustment before onset of illness. Rate if subject found difficulty entering or maintaining normal social relationships, showed persistent social isolation, withdrawal or maintained solitary interests prior to onset of psychotic symptoms. (inst10_120701)

Before you had psychiatric problems for the first time, were you the sort of person who had a lot of friends, or just a few special friends, or no friends? Did you get along easily with other people? Did you tend to do things alone or with other people? Were you suspicious or mistrustful of people? Were you often moody or irritable with other people? Were you ever in trouble with the law before you became ill? Can you tell me about that? (premorbid_social_adjustment)
Notes about premorbid adjustment (premorbid_social_adjustment_notes)

module.longName: 11. Coarse brain disorder prior to onset (OPCRIT 15)

instruction.text: Considerable evidence of a physical illness that could explain most or all psychiatric symptoms. This may include overt brain lesions or marked metabolic disturbances known to cause psychotic symptoms. Nonspecific abnormalities (e.g., enlarged lateral ventricles on brain scan) should not be included.

module.preferredDefinition: 11. Coarse brain disorder prior to onset (OPCRIT 15)

question.questionText: Considerable evidence of a physical illness that could explain most or all psychiatric symptoms. This may include overt brain lesions or marked metabolic disturbances known to cause psychotic symptoms. Nonspecific abnormalities (e.g., enlarged lateral ventricles on brain scan) should not be included. (inst10_1207012_c68)

Were you suffering from any physical or neurological disorders before you first became psychiatrically ill? What was it? How long did you have this problem before psychiatric symptoms appeared? (coarse_brain_disorder)
Notes about coarse brain disorder (coarse_brain_disorder_notes)
12. Family history of schizophrenia (OPCRIT 13) (header_0120701)
First or second degree relative has schizophrenia severe enough to warrant psychiatric referral. (inst10_1207012_c682_978)
Do you know of anyone in your family (including aunts, uncles, cousins) who has had schizophrenia? (family_history_schizophrenia)

module.longName: 13. Family history of psychiatric disorder other than schizophrenia (OPCRIT 14)

instruction.text: First or second degree relative has a psychiatric disorder (other than schizophrenia) severe enough to warrant psychiatric referral.

module.preferredDefinition: 13. Family history of psychiatric disorder other than schizophrenia (OPCRIT 14)

question.questionText: First or second degree relative has a psychiatric disorder (other than schizophrenia) severe enough to warrant psychiatric referral. (inst10_1207012_c682_92_240)

Do you know of anyone in your family (including aunts, uncles, cousins) who has had any other psychiatric disorder? Did they see a doctor for that problem? Have they been in hospital for that problem? Do you know what treatment they received (medications, ECT)? Do you know what the doctors said was wrong with them? (family_history_other_psychiatric_disorder)

validValue.meaningText: Family history of psychiatric disorder other than schizophrenia
validValue.description: Family history of psychiatric disorder other than schizophrenia

question.questionText: Notes about family history: (family_history_notes)

instruction.text: I would now like to ask you about your mood (i.e., how happy or sad you have been).

question.questionText: I would now like to ask you about your mood (i.e., how happy or sad you have been). (inst14_0120701)
14.01 Have you ever been sad, down, depressed, or blue most of the day, nearly every day, for at least one week? (dysphoria_depression)
14.01 How long did you feel like that? (dysphoria_depression_length)

14.02 Have you ever found you were easily irritated, that any little problem provoked you, or that other people said you were much too impatient? Did this last most of the day, nearly every day for at least one week? (dysphoria_irritated_impatient)
14.02 How long did you feel like that? (dysphoria_irritated_impatient_length)

14.02 If more than one episode, interview for the most severe depressive episode. Rate mood on subjective description. Remember that occasional sadness is part of normal human expression it becomes pathological when it is persistent, pervasive, unresponsive, or out of proportion to events or circumstances. (dysphoria_irritated_impatient_more)
Notes about dysphoria (dysphoria_notes)

instruction.text: Pervasive inability to enjoy activities. This should be a definite loss compared with the normal state.

question.questionText: Pervasive inability to enjoy activities. This should be a definite loss compared with the normal state. (desc_120701)

Did you ever have a period of time when you were unable to enjoy things as much as usual? For example, taking a walk, spending time with friends, or working at your hobbies or interests? Did this last most of the day, nearly every day for at least one week? Did you lose interest in your work, recreation activities or your dress and appearance for more than a week? How long did you feel like that? (loss_of_pleasure)
Notes about anhedonia (loss_of_pleasure_notes)
Rate items 16 30 in relation to the most severe depressive episode identified in item 14 (dysphoria) and item 15 (loss of pleasure). (notest15_0120701)

instruction.text: Subjective complaint of being excessively tired, with no energy. There should be a definite loss of energy compared with the normal state.

question.questionText: Subjective complaint of being excessively tired, with no energy. There should be a definite loss of energy compared with the normal state. (desc_1207012_847)

16. During that time, did you have as much energy as usual? Did you get exhausted and worn out during the day, even when you weren't working very hard? Did you feel you had to push yourself to do things? Did you feel as though everything was too much trouble or that you couldn't be bothered? How long did you feel like that? (loss_of_energy)

instruction.text: Subject complains that he/she feels slowed down and unable to move. Others may report subjective feelings of retardation or retardation may be noted by examining clinician.

question.questionText: Subject complains that he/she feels slowed down and unable to move. Others may report subjective feelings of retardation or retardation may be noted by examining clinician. (desc_1207012_8472_e38)

During that time, did you feel as though you were slowed down in your movements or speech? Did your arms and legs feel heavy? Did you feel as though you were talking too slowly? How long did you feel like that? (slowed_activity)

instruction.text: Subjective complaint of being unable to think clearly, make decisions etc., which is a definite loss compared with the normal state.

question.questionText: Subjective complaint of being unable to think clearly, make decisions etc., which is a definite loss compared with the normal state. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_bd8)

During that time, was your concentration as good as usual or did your attention wander? Were you able to read an article in the paper or watch a TV program and pay attention to what you were reading or watching? Could you concentrate sufficiently to complete tasks properly (e.g., cooking, conversation, work)? How long did that last? Was it difficult to make decisions? How long did you feel like that? (impaired_concentration)

instruction.text: Definite and persistent change in sexual drive or interest as compared with before onset of depressive episode.

question.questionText: Definite and persistent change in sexual drive or interest as compared with before onset of depressive episode. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_03c)
During that time, did your interest in sex change? Were you more or less interested in sex? How long did you feel like that? (altered_libido)

validValue.meaningText: Loss of libido for at least one week
validValue.description: Loss of libido for at least one week

validValue.meaningText: Increase in libido for at least one week
validValue.description: Increase in libido for at least one week

instruction.text: Subject describes extreme feelings of guilt or unworthiness.

question.questionText: Subject describes extreme feelings of guilt or unworthiness. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_413)

During that time, did you blame yourself for things you did or thought, or feel very guilty or ashamed of yourself? What kind of things did you blame yourself for or feel guilty about? How much of the time each day did you have these thoughts? Did you have these thoughts nearly every day? How long did you feel like that? (excessive_self_reproach)
Notes about depressive symptoms (depressive_symptoms_notes)

instruction.text: Thinking of suicide, wishing to be dead, attempts to kill self, whether depressed or not. Preoccupation with death, not necessarily one's own death.

question.questionText: Thinking of suicide, wishing to be dead, attempts to kill self, whether depressed or not. Preoccupation with death, not necessarily one's own death. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_542)

During that time, did you feel that life was not worth living? Were you thinking about death or dying a lot? Did you think about harming yourself or even made an attempt at suicide? What happened? When was this? How long did you feel like that? (suicidality)

validValue.meaningText: Suicidal ideation present at least one week or suicide attempt
validValue.description: Suicidal ideation present at least one week or suicide attempt

validValue.meaningText: Suicidal ideation present at least two weeks
validValue.description: Suicidal ideation present at least two weeks

validValue.meaningText: Suicidal ideation present at least one month
validValue.description: Suicidal ideation present at least one month

question.questionText: Notes about suicidality (suicidality_notes)

instruction.text: Subjective complaint of poor appetite, not necessarily observed to be eating less.

question.questionText: Subjective complaint of poor appetite, not necessarily observed to be eating less. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_12d)
During that time, did your appetite decrease? Did you eat the same amount without really enjoying it? How long did that last? (pxt120701_decreased_appetite)

instruction.text: The weight loss must be the result of 'poor appetite' as rated in item 22.

question.questionText: The weight loss must be the result of 'poor appetite' as rated in item 22. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_869)
During that time, did you lose weight? How much weight did you lose? Over what period of time? Were you deliberately trying to lose weight? (weight_loss)

validValue.meaningText: Loss of at least 1+ lb (0.5 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 4 lbs (2 kg) in less than 3 weeks
validValue.description: Loss of at least 1+ lb (0.5 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 4 lbs (2 kg) in less than 3 weeks

validValue.meaningText: Loss of at least 2+ lbs (1 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 5 to 9 lbs (2.5 to 4.5 kg) in less than 3 weeks
validValue.description: Loss of at least 2+ lbs (1 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 5 to 9 lbs (2.5 to 4.5 kg) in less than 3 weeks

validValue.meaningText: Loss of at least 10+ lbs (5 kg) in less than 1 year
validValue.description: Loss of at least 10+ lbs (5 kg) in less than 1 year

instruction.text: Subject reports increased appetite or 'comfort eating'.

question.questionText: Subject reports increased appetite or 'comfort eating'. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_0e2)
During that time, did your appetite increase? Sometimes when people feel depressed they comfort eat did you do that? How long did that last? (pxt120701_increased_appetite)
Thinking of suicide, wishing to be dead, attempts to kill self, whether depressed or not. Preoccupation with death, not necessarily one's own death. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_b71)

During that time, did you gain weight? How much weight did you gain? Over what period of time? Were you deliberately trying to gain weight? Do you think it was a result of medication you are taking? (weight_gain)

validValue.meaningText: Gain of at least 1+ lb (0.5 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 4 lbs (2 kg) in less than 3 weeks
validValue.description: Gain of at least 1+ lb (0.5 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 4 lbs (2 kg) in less than 3 weeks

validValue.meaningText: Gain of at least 2+ lbs (1 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 5 to 9 lbs (2.5 to 4.5 kg) in less than 3 weeks
validValue.description: Gain of at least 2+ lbs (1 kg) per week for 3 or more weeks or 5 to 9 lbs (2.5 to 4.5 kg) in less than 3 weeks

validValue.meaningText: Gain of at least 10+ lbs (5 kg) in less than 1 year
validValue.description: Gain of at least 10+ lbs (5 kg) in less than 1 year

question.questionText: Note: Do not rate if there is clear evidence that weight gain is related to medications such as atypical antipsychotics, antidepressants, or steroids. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_7c4)

instruction.text: Subject complains that he/she is unable to fall asleep and lies awake for at least one hour.

question.questionText: Subject complains that he/she is unable to fall asleep and lies awake for at least one hour. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_735)
During that time, did you have problems falling asleep? How long did it take you to get to sleep? How long did you have problems falling asleep? (initial_insomnia)

instruction.text: Sleep is disturbed on most nights subject wakes in the middle of sleep and experiences difficulty in getting back to sleep.

question.questionText: Sleep is disturbed on most nights subject wakes in the middle of sleep and experiences difficulty in getting back to sleep. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_617)
During that time, did you wake during the night? How many times each night? Did you have difficulty getting back to sleep? How long did you lie awake before you fell asleep again? (middle_insomnia)

instruction.text: Use frequency and time probes, making due allowances for unusual working hours. Subject complains that he/she persistently wakes up at least one hour earlier than usual waking time.

question.questionText: Use frequency and time probes, making due allowances for unusual working hours. Subject complains that he/she persistently wakes up at least one hour earlier than usual waking time. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_10a)

During that time, did you wake up much earlier than usual? What time do you usually wake up in the morning when you are sleeping normally? Were you waking much earlier than this? Were you able to get back to sleep? How long did you have problems waking up too early? (terminal_insomnia)

instruction.text: Subject complains of sleeping at least two hours longer than usual, more or less daily. May be accompanied by irresistible sleepiness, and/or a period of 'sleep drunkenness after waking.

question.questionText: Subject complains of sleeping at least two hours longer than usual, more or less daily. May be accompanied by irresistible sleepiness, and/or a period of 'sleep drunkenness after waking. (desc_1207012_8472_e382_b29)
29.01 During that time, were you sleeping much more than usual? How many hours do you normally sleep? (excessive_sleep_normal_hours)
29.02 During that time, were you sleeping much more than usual? How many hours were you sleeping then? (excessive_sleep_new_hours)
During that time, were you sleeping much more than usual? How long did you have problems sleeping more than usual? (excessive_sleep_length)
Was there any time of the day when the depression felt worse? (diurnal_variation)

validValue.meaningText: No depression, or not worse early
validValue.description: No depression, or not worse early

validValue.meaningText: Regularly feels worse early in the day
validValue.description: Regularly feels worse early in the day

question.questionText: Notes about appetite or sleep changes (appetite_sleep_changes_notes)
31. Elevated mood (OPCRIT 35) (question31_0120701)
Subject's predominant mood is one of elation and is out of proportion to circumstances. (instr3_0120701)

I have asked you some questions about depression I now want to ask about whether you have ever felt the opposite of depressed (i.e., intensely happy or elated), in a way that was clearly different than your normal self? (elevated_mood)

validValue.meaningText: Present at least two weeks OR if lasted < one week but hospitalized for affective disorder
validValue.description: Present at least two weeks OR if lasted < one week but hospitalized for affective disorder

question.questionText: Subject's mood is predominantly irritable. (instr3_01207012_c54)

Have you ever felt very irritable or excessively annoyed with others, such that you lost your temper often, shouted at people, or even got into fights? Did other people comment on that or say you were much too impatient? Can you describe that feeling? Was it out of character for you? How long were you feeling like that? (irritable_mood)

validValue.meaningText: Present at least two weeks OR if lasted < one week but hospitalized for affective disorder
validValue.description: Present at least two weeks OR if lasted < one week but hospitalized for affective disorder

question.questionText: Notes about elevated or irritable mood: (elevated_irritable_mood_notes)

If NO to item 31 (elevated mood) and item 32 (irritable mood) SKIP to item 41 (hallucinations). Rate items 33 40 in relation to the most severe manic episode identified in item 31 (elevated mood) and item 32 (irritable mood). (instr_0120701)

instruction.text: Subject is much more talkative than usual or there seems to be undue pressure to get the words out. Speech may be over elaborated with unnecessary words added. Include manic type of formal thought disorder with clang associations, punning and rhyming, etc.

question.questionText: Subject is much more talkative than usual or there seems to be undue pressure to get the words out. Speech may be over elaborated with unnecessary words added. Include manic type of formal thought disorder with clang associations, punning and rhyming, etc. (instr3_01207012_c542_e27)

During that time, were you more talkative than usual or did you feel pressure to keep on talking? Did you talk so much or so fast that it was difficult for people to follow what you were saying? How long were you acting like that? (pressured_speech)

instruction.text: Subject experiences thoughts racing through his/her head or others observe flight of ideas that make it difficult to follow what subject is talking about.

question.questionText: Subject experiences thoughts racing through his/her head or others observe flight of ideas that make it difficult to follow what subject is talking about. (instr3_01207012_c542_2_89b)

During that time, did you find your thoughts crowding into or racing through your mind so that you felt like you couldn't keep up with them? Can you describe what that felt like? How long were you feeling like that? (racing_thoughts)

instruction.text: Subject's predominant mood is one of elation and is out of proportion to circumstances.

question.questionText: Subject's predominant mood is one of elation and is out of proportion to circumstances. (instr3_01207012_c542_2_f57)
During that time, were you easily distracted by irrelevant things happening around you? Can you describe what that felt like? How long were you feeling like that? (distractibility)

instruction.text: Subject sleeps much less but there is no complaint of insomnia. Extra waking time is usually taken up with excessive activities.

question.questionText: Subject sleeps much less but there is no complaint of insomnia. Extra waking time is usually taken up with excessive activities. (instr3_01207012_c542_2_6c1)
36.01 During that time, did you need far less sleep than usual without feeling tired? How many hours do you normally sleep? (mania_reduced_need_for_sleep)
36.02 During that time, did you need far less sleep than usual without feeling tired? How many hours were you sleeping then? (mania_hours_asleep)

During that time, did you need far less sleep than usual without feeling tired? (Subject sleeps much less but there is no complaint of insomnia. Extra waking time is usually taken up with excessive activities.) (mania_no_insomnia_complaint)

instruction.text: Subject is markedly overactive and has tremendous energy. Overactivity includes speech, motor, social, and sexual activity.

question.questionText: Subject is markedly overactive and has tremendous energy. Overactivity includes speech, motor, social, and sexual activity. (instr3_01207012_c542_2_f6f)

During that time, were you taking on more tasks or being more active than usual so active that you or others thought something was wrong? What sort of things were you doing? How long were you acting like that? (excessive_activity)

instruction.text: Subject is excessively involved in activities with high potential for painful consequences which is not recognized, e.g., excessive spending, sexual indiscretions, reckless driving, gambling etc.

question.questionText: Subject is excessively involved in activities with high potential for painful consequences which is not recognized, e.g., excessive spending, sexual indiscretions, reckless driving, gambling etc. (instr3_01207012_c542_2_d07)

During that time, did you do anything that could have gotten you into trouble like spending too much money, making foolish business investments, have sexual indiscretions, or drive recklessly? Did any problems happen because of this? Did people think you were being reckless or foolish? Did you do things you later regretted? How long were you acting like that? (reckless_activity)

During that time, were you being much more sociable than usual? In what way? Do you think you were being overly friendly with other people? What sort of things were you doing? How long were you acting like that? (increased_sociability)

instruction.text: Subject believes that he/she is an exceptional person with special powers, plans, talents or abilities. Rate positively here if overvalued idea.

question.questionText: Subject believes that he/she is an exceptional person with special powers, plans, talents or abilities. Rate positively here if overvalued idea. (instr3_01207012_c542_2_3b5)

During that time, did you have grand beliefs or ideas that you later found out were not true? Like believing that you had special powers or abilities others did not have? Or that you could accomplish much more at work or in your daily activities, as if you had super powers or talents? How long did you feel like that? (increased_self_esteem)
Notes about hypomanic or manic symptoms (mania_hypomania_notes)

instruction.text: I would now like to ask some questions that we ask everybody.

question.questionText: I would now like to ask some questions that we ask everybody. (instrthallucinations_0120701)
Feels sexual sensations or other stimulation when no one is present. (instrthallucinations_2_5f8)

Auditory: Have you ever heard noises or voices when there is nobody around and no ordinary explanation seems possible? Visual: Have you ever had visions or seen things that other people could not see? Olfactory: Have you ever noticed unusual smells that you could not account for? Somatic: Have you ever experienced any strange sensations in your body (e.g., touch, or temperature, or pain, or floating, or being weightless)? Or crawling sensations under the skin? Sexual or other: Have you ever experienced any unusual sexual sensations without external stimulation? Or strange tastes in your mouth that you couldn't account for? Can you describe those experiences? What is the explanation? Could these be your own thoughts? How frequently did this happen? How long were you having experiences like that? (hallucinations_in_any_modality)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Notes about hallucinations: (hallucinations_in_any_modality_notes)

instruction.text: Include neutral voices and nonverbal hallucinations, such as tapping, hissing, etc.

question.questionText: Include neutral voices and nonverbal hallucinations, such as tapping, hissing, etc. (inst42_120701)

Have you ever heard noises like music or birds or muttering or whispering that no one else can hear? Can you describe what you heard? Could you make out if there are any words? How often has this happened? How long were you hearing these things? (neutral_voices_nonverbal_hallucinations)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

module.longName: 43. Command, accusatory, abusive, or persecutory voices (OPCRIT 75)

instruction.text: Voices talking to the subject in an accusatory, abusive, persecutory or commanding manner.

module.preferredDefinition: 43. Command, accusatory, abusive, or persecutory voices (OPCRIT 75)

question.questionText: Voices talking to the subject in an accusatory, abusive, persecutory or commanding manner. (inst42_1207012_df9)

Did you ever hear voices that told you what to do, said bad things about you, or put you down? What did the voices say? Was there more than one voice? How often did this happen? How long did you hear the voices? (command_accusatory_abusive_persecutory_voices)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

instruction.text: Subject hears voices describing his/her actions, sensations, or emotions as they occur.

question.questionText: Subject hears voices describing his/her actions, sensations, or emotions as they occur. (inst42_1207012_df92_fb3)

Did you ever hear voices that commented on what you are thinking or doing? For example, describing what you are reading, or watching on television, or commenting on what you are doing as you do it? How often did this happen? How long did you hear the voices? (running_commentary)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

instruction.text: Rate two or more voices discussing the subject in the third person.

question.questionText: Rate two or more voices discussing the subject in the third person. (inst42_1207012_df92_f2_bc6)

Did you ever hear voices talking to each other about you, rather than talking directly to you? What did they say to each other? How often did this happen? How long did you hear the voices? (third_person_auditory_hallucinations)

question.questionText: Notes about hallucinations (auditory_hallucinations_notes)
46. Thought insertion (OPCRIT 66) (question46_0120701)
Recognizes that thoughts are being put into his/her head which are not his/her own and which have probably or definitely been inserted by some external agency. (inst42_1207012_df92_f2_3a6)

Did you ever have thoughts in your mind which were not your own which seemed to come from somewhere outside you? Who or what did you think was putting those thoughts into your mind? How often has this happened? How long did you have these thoughts? (thought_insertion)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

instruction.text: The experience must be described of thoughts diffusing out of subject's mind so they can be shared or even heard by others. The experience is passive, i.e., not willed by subject. Exclude delusions that subject's own thoughts are quoted on TV, in newspapers, etc. Exclude merely the belief that thoughts are being read.

question.questionText: The experience must be described of thoughts diffusing out of subject's mind so they can be shared or even heard by others. The experience is passive, i.e., not willed by subject. Exclude delusions that subject's own thoughts are quoted on TV, in newspapers, etc. Exclude merely the belief that thoughts are being read. (inst42_1207012_df92_f2_69e)

Have your thoughts ever seemed to be public not private to yourself, so that others knew what you were thinking? Did it feel like your thoughts were being broadcasted to other people? Did you ever feel as if other people could hear your thoughts? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (thought_broadcast)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Subject experiences thoughts ceasing in his/her head, which may be a "thought block" being interpreted as thoughts being removed or "stolen" by some external agency. Must describe active extraction, not "thoughts seem to be outside my head." The experience is not willed by the subject. (inst42_1207012_df92_f2_c33)
Did you ever feel that your thoughts were being taken out of or sent out of your head? Can you describe that? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (thought_withdrawal)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Subject experiences thoughts repeated or echoed in his or her head. (inst42_1207012_df92_f2_d45)

Did a single thought in your mind ever seem to be repeated over and over as you thought it? Was it like an echo of a voice? Can you describe that? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (thought_echo)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Notes about subjective thought disturbances (subjective_thought_disturbances_notes)
I now want to ask you about any odd or unusual experiences you might have had. (question51_0120701)

I now want to ask you about any odd or unusual experiences you might have had. Have you ever had beliefs or ideas that others did not share or later found out were not true like people being against you, people trying to harm you, or people talking about you, or believing you were given special messages (e.g., through the TV or the radio)? (screen_for_delusions)
Firm belief held by subject that he/she has committed some sin, crime or caused harm to others despite absence of any evidence to support this. (ins120701)

Have you ever been convinced that you committed a crime, sinned greatly, or deserved punishment? Did you really believe that these thoughts were true? Did you believe these things only when you were feeling depressed? How often has this happened? How long did you feel like that? (delusions_of_guilt)
Firm belief held by subject that he/she has lost all or much of their money or property and has become impoverished despite the absence of any evidence to support this. (ins1207012_81b)

Have you ever had needless concerns about your financial situation? For example, having thoughts about being ruined and doomed to die in poverty? Or fearing that you would have no means to support yourself or your family? Did you actually lose money or property? How often has this happened? How long did you feel like that? (delusions_of_poverty)

Firmly held belief (i.e., delusional intensity), that some part of subject's body has disappeared or is rotting away or is affected by some devastating or malignant disorder despite a lack of any objective supporting evidence. (ins1207012_81b2_707)

Have you ever believed that your body was unhealthy or strangely diseased (e.g., that your bowels were stopped up, or that your insides had rotted away, or that some part of your body was missing)? Did you ever have thoughts like that? Can you describe what you felt was wrong with your body? Were you experiencing any serious health problems at that time? How often has this happened? How long did you feel like that? (nihilistic_delusions)

Subject knows that his/her own feelings, impulses, volitional acts, or bodily sensations are controlled or imposed by an external agency. Include all 'made' sensations, emotions or actions. The experience of replacement is essential, the will is experienced as diminished or replaced by that of some other agency. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_970)

Did you ever feel like your will had been replaced by some force or power outside yourself? Did you feel that your intentions were replaced by those of some external power? Were your feelings controlled, or created by something or somebody outside yourself? Was it like being a robot, zombie, or puppet, controlled from elsewhere? Can you describe that? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (delusions_of_passivity)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Events, objects or other people in subject's immediate surroundings have a special significance, often of a persecutory nature. Include ideas of reference from the TV or radio, or newspapers, where subject believes that these are providing instructions or prescribing certain behavior. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_7c4)

Have people ever seemed to drop hints meant for you, or say things with double meanings? Did you see messages for yourself in the newspapers or on TV or radio? Did you feel that something or person around you was giving you special messages? Do you sometimes see coded messages in how objects are arranged or in how things happen? Can you describe that? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (delusions_of_influence)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Includes all delusions with persecutory ideation, such as belief that someone is trying to harm them damage their reputation or drive them mad without reasonable cause. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_36d)

Have you ever felt that people were deliberately acting to harm you? Were they particularly singling you out? Have you felt that a group of people was plotting to cause you harm or injury? Can you describe what might have been happening? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (persecutory_delusions)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Subject has grossly exaggerated sense of own importance, has exceptional abilities or believes that he/she is rich or famous, titled or related to royalty. Also included are delusions of identification with God, angels, the Messiah, etc. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_749)

Have you ever felt that you had any special powers, talents, or abilities much more than other people? Have you ever felt that you had a special purpose, mission, or identity? Or that you were rich or famous, or related to prominent people? Or, maybe, that you had been chosen by God for a special mission? Do you believe that this really is true? How long have you felt like this? (grandiose_delusions)

A delusional mood is a strange mood in which the environment appears changed in a threatening way but the significance of the change cannot be understood by the subject who is usually tense, anxious or bewildered. A delusional idea appears abruptly in the subject's mind fully developed and is unrelated to other thoughts or perceptions. If a delusional idea is described, code it on item 59 (primary delusional ideas). (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_57d)

Did you ever have the feeling that something odd was going on that you couldn't explain? Can you describe what you felt was happening? Have you felt puzzled by strange happenings that were difficult to account for? Did familiar surroundings seem strange? How often has this happened? How long did you feel like that? (delusional_moods)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Note: These are rare. If in doubt, rate this down. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_99a)

Intrusive, often sudden knowledge of a radically transformed meaning of a common perception. Subject has an ordinary perception which triggers a firmly held false belief. The belief arises from the perception in an inexplicable way. Example: a woman saw a plane cross the sun and at once knew that alien beings had chosen her for their ambassador on the earth. Exclude if apparently based on abnormal mood, or is part of a culture bound religious experience. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_c35)

When you experienced [examples of delusions from items 51 58], how did you know what it meant? Did you know at once what it meant? Did you have any other experiences that made you suspect something like this might happen? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (primary_delusional_ideas)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Note: These are rare. If in doubt, rate this down. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_50d)

Delusions are deemed "bizarre" if they are clearly implausible, not understandable, and do not derive from ordinary experiences. Strange, absurd or fantastic delusions that are physically impossible, e.g., "my skin is inside out" or "there were real little people inside the TV". The delusional content may have a mystical, magical or 'science fiction' quality. Consider the subject's cultural, educational and social background. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_5cc)

Have you ever had any odd or unusual experiences things that other people don't usually experience or things that other people might find hard to believe? Can you give me an example? Did you ever feel influenced or affected by Xrays, radio waves or machines or anything like that? How often has this happened? How long did this experience last? (bizarre_delusions)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Notes about delusions (delusions_notes)

Rate here overall insight into nature of psychotic symptoms more generally, including associated behavior. Subject is unable to recognize that his/her experiences are abnormal or that they are the product of anomalous mental processes, or recognizes that his/her experiences are abnormal but gives a delusional explanation. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_88a)

Do you feel you are or have been psychiatrically ill? If Yes, how do you explain it? Do you think you needed to see a doctor or psychiatrist? Do you think you need medication and/or treatment? (insight)

module.longName: 62. Relationship between psychotic and affective symptoms (OPCRIT 52)
module.preferredDefinition: 62. Relationship between psychotic and affective symptoms (OPCRIT 52)

question.questionText: Let us review what you told me about [refer to specific psychotic experiences: delusions, hallucinations, or subjective thought disorder], and also what you said about changes in your mood or feelings. Would you say that the two always occur together, or seem to be independent of one another? (psychotic_affective_symptoms_relationship)

validValue.meaningText: Psychotic symptoms dominate the clinical picture although occasional affective disturbance may also occur.
validValue.description: Psychotic symptoms dominate the clinical picture although occasional affective disturbance may also occur.

validValue.meaningText: Psychotic and affective symptoms are balanced, with neither group of symptoms dominating the overall course of the illness.
validValue.description: Psychotic and affective symptoms are balanced, with neither group of symptoms dominating the overall course of the illness.

validValue.meaningText: Affective symptoms predominate although psychotic symptoms may also occur.
validValue.description: Affective symptoms predominate although psychotic symptoms may also occur.

question.questionText: Notes about insight or about relationship between psychotic and affective symptoms (psychotic_affective_symptoms_notes)

module.longName: 63. Psychotic symptoms respond to antipsychotic medications (OPCRIT 89)
module.preferredDefinition: 63. Psychotic symptoms respond to antipsychotic medications (OPCRIT 89)

question.questionText: Use all information available and rate globally over total period. Illness appears to respond to any type of neuroleptics, (depot or oral) OR if relapse occurs when medication is stopped. This is not a subjective judgment by the subject but an objective rating by the interviewer. (ins1207012_81b2_7072_2_7f6)

What medications are you currently taking? Do you feel the medications have helped in any way? If yes, how? Have you ever taken any medications that you felt were helpful in any way? If yes, how? (psychotic_symptoms_respond_to_antipsychotics)

validValue.meaningText: No response to neuroleptics, never been psychotic, or never taken neuroleptics
validValue.description: No response to neuroleptics, never been psychotic, or never taken neuroleptics

question.questionText: Record past and present neuroleptic / antipsychotic medications. Do not include antidepressants or mood stabilizers. (notes63_0120701_1)
Review all responses. Make sure you have sufficient information to answer all interviewer rated items. End interview and thank the participant. (notes63_0120701_2)

Before completing interviewer ratings, review the subject's responses to all interview questions. Clarify any inconsistencies and make sure that all questions have been answered. Then complete interviewer ratings beginning with item 64. (notes63_0120701_3)

64. Note: Base the rating on the extent to which all the delusions have a common theme or development. Systematization implies that if the initial premise is granted, the rest of the delusion is logically constructed and internally consistent. (notes63_0120701_32_a9b)

module.longName: H. INTERVIEWER RATINGS OF PSYCHOTIC SYMPTOM
module.preferredDefinition: H. INTERVIEWER RATINGS OF PSYCHOTIC SYMPTOM

question.questionText: 64. Well organized delusions (OPCRIT 55) (well_organized_delusions)

question.questionText: 65. Note: Delusions which intrude into most aspects of the subject's life and/or preoccupy the subject for most of his/her time. (notes63_0120701_32_a92_0fb)
65. Widespread delusions (OPCRIT 60) (widespread_delusions)

question.questionText: 66. Note:Any type of delusion accompanied by hallucinations of any type lasting at least one week (both at the same time). (notes63_0120701_32_a92_9cc)
66. Delusions and hallucinations last for one week (OPCRIT 64) (delusions_hallucinations_last_one_week)

question.questionText: 67. Note: The abnormal beliefs are of delusional intensity and quality and are accompanied by hallucinations (both at the same time). (notes63_0120701_32_a92_bc5)

module.longName: I. INTERVIEWER RATINGS OF DURATION AND COURSE
module.preferredDefinition: I. INTERVIEWER RATINGS OF DURATION AND COURSE

question.questionText: Use all available information to determine the following ratings. (q61_instr_0120701)

Total duration of illness includes PRODROMAL and RESIDUAL disabilities as well as the active phase of illness. This must be calculated from first onset of disorder regardless of pattern or course of illness. Refer to question 6 to help determine the number of weeks of prodromal symptoms. Prodromal or residual phase is when any 2 of the following symptoms are present before (prodromal) or after (residual) an active episode: Social isolation / marked impairment in role Markedly peculiar behavior Marked impairment in personal hygiene Blunted, flat or inappropriate affect Digressive, vague, overelaborate speech Odd or bizarre ideations Unusual perceptual experiences. (duration_of_illness_in_weeks)
Note: the range is from 0 99. (q61range_0120701)
69. Impairment or incapacity during disorder (OPCRIT 87) Note: Rate on basis of worst episode. (impairment_or_incapacity_during_disorder)

validValue.meaningText: Subjective impairment only (at work, school, family or social functioning).
validValue.description: Subjective impairment only (at work, school, family or social functioning).

validValue.meaningText: Evidence of objective functional impairment in major life role with definite reduction in productivity and/or criticism about functioning or performance has been received.
validValue.description: Evidence of objective functional impairment in major life role with definite reduction in productivity and/or criticism about functioning or performance has been received.

validValue.meaningText: Inpatient treatment (any duration) has been received, or no functioning at all in major life role for more than two days, or active psychotic symptoms such as delusions or hallucinations have occurred.
validValue.description: Inpatient treatment (any duration) has been received, or no functioning at all in major life role for more than two days, or active psychotic symptoms such as delusions or hallucinations have occurred.

module.longName: 70. Deterioration from premorbid level of functioning (OPCRIT 88)
module.preferredDefinition: 70. Deterioration from premorbid level of functioning (OPCRIT 88)

question.questionText: Has not regained premorbid social, occupational or emotional functioning after an acute episode of illness. For a significant portion of the time since onset there has been deterioration in work, interpersonal relations, or selfcare. If the onset was in childhood or adolescence, there has been failure to achieve the expected interpersonal, academic, or occupational level. (deterioration_from_premorbid_functioning_level)

validValue.meaningText: Deterioration from premorbid level of functioning
validValue.description: Deterioration from premorbid level of functioning

question.questionText: 71. Course of disorder (OPCRIT 90) (course_of_disorder)

validValue.meaningText: Multiple episodes with good recovery between (2)
validValue.description: Multiple episodes with good recovery between (2)

validValue.meaningText: Multiple episodes with partial recovery between (3)
validValue.description: Multiple episodes with partial recovery between (3)

question.questionText: Note: Rate clinical symptoms and functional impairment Score this item in hierarchal fashion. If subject's course in past rated 2, but subsequently changed to 4, then the correct rating is 4. If in doubt, rate down (i.e., 2 rather than 3). (q71instr_0120701)

Rapport difficult. Interviewer finds difficulty in establishing contact with subject and in conducting examination because the subject appears remote. Does not include subjects who are difficult to interview because of hostility or irritability. Use your own judgment to rate the adequacy of information from medical records. (rapport)
Note: If rating from case records, rate 1 'rapport difficult' if poor quality information from case records. (instr72_0120701)

Subject gives misleading answers to questions or provides a jumbled, incoherent or inconsistent account. When rating from medical records, use own judgment to rate validity of available information. (credibility_of_information)

module.longName: J. INTERVIEWER RATINGS OF BEHAVIORS AND AFFECT
module.preferredDefinition: J. INTERVIEWER RATINGS OF BEHAVIORS AND AFFECT

question.questionText: Rate the following items on the basis of observation during the interview, history, and review of medical records when available. Must have a well documented history of symptom if the symptom is not present at time of interview. (instrj_0120701)

Mannerisms: Odd, idiosyncratic movements or actions, e.g., tapping foot four times before entering a doorway, may be suggestive of specific meaning or purpose. Stereotypes: Simple, repetitive movements, e.g., rocking, rubbing, nodding, swaying, feeling surfaces, which do not seem to have special significance. Posturing: Assumes and maintains for >10 minutes, or even hours at a time, odd postures of parts of body which would be very difficult for most people to sustain for long periods. Flexibilitas cerea: The muscles of a limb become fairly rigid (e.g., if an arm is raised by an examiner into a certain position, the patient will hold it for > 15 seconds). Stupor: Total or nearly total lack of spontaneous movement and marked decrease of reactivity to the environment. Excitement: Bouts of uncontrollable, chaotic overactivity (e.g., running around the room, jumping, perhaps shouting, may throw things or be aggressive during such episodes). (catatonia)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Grossly odd appearance or behaviors likely to be determined by the subject's psychotic symptoms, for example clothes or ornaments having special significance to the subject (do not include eccentricity determined by membership in a specific social or cultural group). ncludes behavior suggestive of response to auditory hallucinations or thought interference (e.g., lips moving soundlessly looks around as if voices might be calling). (bizarre_behavior)
Note: These behaviors do not necessarily indicate hallucinations or thought interference. (notes75_0120701)
Excessive repetitive activity, such as fidgety restlessness, wringing of hands, pacing up and down, all usually accompanied by expression of mental anguish. (agitated_activity)
Subject's emotional responses are restricted in range and at interview there is an impression of bland indifference or 'lack of contact.' (restricted_affect)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: A global diminution of emotional response. Subject's emotional responses are persistently flat and show a complete failure to 'resonate' to external change. The difference between restricted and blunted affect should be regarded as one of degree, with 'blunted' only being rated in extreme cases. (blunted_affect)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: The range of emotional expression is not necessarily diminished but the subject's emotional responses are inappropriate to the circumstance (e.g., laughter when discussing painful or sad occurrences, fatuous giggling without apparent reason). (inappropriate_affect)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Rambling on in a vague, muddled way, beginning more or less on the point but gradually wandering far from it. The overall effect is one of speech that is difficult to understand but short sections of speech may appear within normal limits. Speech makes communication difficult because of a lack of logical or understandable organization (does not include dysarthria or speech impediment). (speech_difficult_to_understand)
As above but with added distortion of grammar. Normal grammatical sentence construction has broken down. Includes word salad"." (speech_incoherent)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Note: Rate conservatively for only extreme forms of formal thought disorder. (note81_0120701)

Subject has fluent speech but tends to communicate poorly due to neologisms (made up words), bizarre use of words, derailments, or loosening of associations. Lack of logical connection between parts of a sentence or between sentences Totally unexpected shifts from topic to topic Answers past the point Answers have little relevance to the questions asked Bizarre use of words and phrases Words that have generally no accepted meaning (positive_formal_thought_disorder)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

question.questionText: Rate any of the following items: Blocking: Sudden interruption in speech without reason and then begins again on same or different topic. Not distraction, lapse of attention, lack of understanding. Poverty of content of speech: Talks freely but so vaguely that little information is given in spite of the number of words used. Exclude incoherence or flight of ideas. Rate only if severe. Restricted quantity of speech: Frequently fails to answer, questions have to be repeated, restricted to minimum necessary, no extra sentences, no additional comments. (negative_formal_thought_disorder)

validValue.meaningText: Present less than one month or duration unspecified
validValue.description: Present less than one month or duration unspecified

validValue.meaningText: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer
validValue.description: Present most of the time in a one month period or longer

protocol.preferredDefinition: The DI-PAD or Diagnostic Instrument for Psychoses and Affective Disorders is an 83 question interviewer-administered instrument designed to elicit information regarding a research subject's functioning and psychopathology with particular emphasis on affective disorders and schizophrenia. It is an American-English adaptation of the Diagnostic Interview for Psychoses ((DIP) Castle et al., 2006)
